jacs.config

Class SystemPortsList

  • java.lang.Object
    • jacs.config.SystemPortsList

  • public class SystemPortsList
extends java.lang.Object
    This class supports detection and selection of correct serial port has been assigned by the operating system to a microcontroller card plugged into a USB port.

    Under some circumstances, it is easy to guess which is the correct port by using a combination of string filters and position in the returned array. But this is not always possible. Under some platform configurations, such as when multiple USB ports are in use, it may be necessary for a user to select the correct port from this list in order for the Show Player or other functionality demonstrated in test programs in jacs.demos to work.

    Author:
    galford

      • SystemPortsList

        public SystemPortsList()

    • Method Detail

      • getServoControllerPorts

        public static java.lang.String[] getServoControllerPorts()
        This uses a string filter to return a list of serial ports names assigned by the underlying operating system based on typical port assignment used when attaching a a Pololu or Arduino card to a USB under Windows 7 or Mac OS X.
        Returns:
        Array of (abridged) port names assigned by the operating system.

        In Windows, these are simply "COM ##", in Mac OS X, these begin with "/dev/cu"

        An empty array if no ports can be found.

      • findPortForController

        public static java.lang.String findPortForController(java.lang.String microcontrollerName)
        This attempts to automatically return the correct serial command port to use for communicating with a Pololu or Arduino has been attached via USB on either a Windows 7 or a Mac OS X system.

        It is an automated best guess. It is provided for convenience for a common case; however operator selection of the correct port may be necessary under some configurations. In that case, method getServoControllerPorts can be used to present a selection list to the operator.

        Parameters:
        microcontrollerName - The name of supported controllers, found in Microcontroller
        Returns:
        A single port name if a reasonable guess exists, otherwise an empty string.
